text.p: Novell Inc. said Friday that Joseph Marengi will resign as president and chief operating officer of the networking company at the end of June.
The departure follows the appointment of Eric Schmidt, the former chief technology officer of Sun Microsystems Inc., as chairman and chief executive earlier this year.
Marengi himself had been a top contender for the posts.
Schmidt, who will assume the responsibilities of president, said Marengi was a friend he had hoped would stay on.
Austin Edgington, a spokesman for Novell, said Marengi would be departing on amicable terms.
"Joe has made a personal decision to move on," the spokesman said. "He has been pretty instrumental in driving the company and also in bringing Eric Schmidt in."

Marengi had served as president since September, leading Novell during a critical period while the company was searching for a new chief executive following the departure of Bob Frankenberg a month earlier.
Marengi, who joined Novell in 1989, was executive vice president of worldwide sales at the company from 1992 to 1996.

Rumours of Marengi's departure were reported on Thursday by Computer Reseller News Online, which cited sources close to the company as saying the Novell marketing veteran had received a lucrative severance package.
Edgington declined to comment on severance. Schmidt and Marengi were not available.

Marengi's departure comes on the heels of Novell's announcement last week that it will cut 1,000 workers -- equal to about 18 percent of its work force -- after it was hit by declining sales of its computer network software. The cuts by Novell, based in Provo, Utah, rank among the largest ever by a computer software company.

The second biggest publisher of personal computer software behind Microsoft Corp., Novell last week reported a loss of $14.6 million, or 4 cents a share, in its second quarter ended on April 30, compared with a loss of $55.4 million, or 15 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose to $273.1 million from $188.2 million.
The company said will take a third-quarter charge of $25 million to $35 million to pay for the layoffs. Novell's stock was barely changed at $7.69 on Nasdaq.
